ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to better relate and synthesize seemingly disparate pieces of work. I also learned about the use of animals in literature over time. I came out with more questions than I entered with but those questions are better informed!
I learned to think critically about humans place in the world as well as our ability to affect the environment.
The ability to critically evaluate the writers intent; thematically; and look for underlying patterns.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The seminar was engaging, and Professor Berger made sure to include everyone in the conversation, especially if they were not participating much on a particular day. The class felt somewhat like a book club and was very enjoyable. It was hard to keep up with all the readings, though!

It could have been effective to ask students what they were most excited to discuss about the books in the beginning of the class periods and build off of those topics. Or, at least discuss in the beginning of the class what the plan was for the day. I sometimes felt like I had questions or connections I wanted to make but which I never found time to bring up. Maybe we even could have submitted a few preparatory questions before the lectures.

I think Professor Berger could have given a few seconds more time after asking us if we had anything to add. Especially in a virtual world, it takes some time to speak up.

I also thought the discussion board was a good idea, but maybe could have been a bit more structured.

Finally, maybe a slightly more accurate name could have been useful. :)

Overall, I loved the class and it sufficiently satisfied my curiosity!
In my experience, the discussions we had each week were very fruitful and thought-provoking. I would have appreciated more discussion threads on canvas to continue our conversations.
I thought the course was excellent and cannot imagine how Dr. Berger could improve on it!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Engaging those of us who weren't speaking up much in a particular lecture was effective.
It would have been nice to wait longer between asking a question (especially whether we had anything else to add) and expecting a response.
Generally, the virtual seminar worked well!
As a small seminar, this class transferred really well to Zoom. Professor Berger was able to manage participation and recreate a comfortable discussion atmosphere like one in the classroom.
The course was completely virtual. We had relatively few technical glitches.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course especially if they're a fast reader! It was fun, engaging, and helped me make connections I never would have considered. Just note that you will need to come to class ready to engage! And, that the class isn't perfectly named... it's not all American, modern, or fiction. There's even one book without animals. :)

Yes! It was a very fun time Prof. Berger is a really interesting man, and has a really broad interest in the topics. The syllabus has a huge range  every week is very different. The atmosphere for discussion was super chill.

I would recommend this course to someone looking to learn about the relationships between the environment, animals, and humans. I would not recommend this course to someone looking to read modern, American fiction about animals.
Absolutely. Exploring the non-human animal in American Fiction was a new opportunity for me and Dr.Berger did an excellent job teaching us how.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

extras.title:
ENGL 281 01/AMST 358 01
        Animals in Modrn Amer Fiction
